mentions.context: SVJedi performs the read mapping internally using minimap2, while cuteSV, Sniffles2, and LRcaller take as input the results of the read mapping done externally.
SVJedi was run on the ONT reads with the parameter "-d ont," and on both PacBio datasets with the default parameter "-d pb."
SVJedi showed an impaired genotyping rate of 25.5%, which was to be expected considering its difficulties to assign genotypes in the context of close and overlapping SVs.
CuteSV and Sniffles2 were run with their "force call" option to genotype a given set of SVs, bypassing the SV discovery steps.
CuteSV and Sniffles genotyping accuracy starts decreasing as soon as deletions are <1000 bp apart, falling $80% and 90%, respectively, for overlapping or adjacent deletions.
SVJedi-graph still maintains a high accuracy as long as the imprecision is smaller than 200 bp (98.8% for 200 bp breakpoint shifts).

SVJedi genotypes a lower proportion of deletions than insertions (85.8% against 93.6%), while all other four genotypers show a relatively stable genotyping rate between both SV types (at most 0.8 point % difference).
SVJedi-graph shows similar genotyping for both PacBio datasets, whereas a small decrease in accuracy with ONT reads (of about 4 points %) with a slight increase in rate (of 0.5-1 point %).

LRcaller has five methods to genotype SVs, we used the joint method as done in the benchmark paper for SV genotyping methods (Duan et al. 2022) with the argument "-gtm joint."

SVJedi-graph results on deletions and insertions are very contrasted, both on % of identical genotypes and on genotyping rate.
As SVJedi uses minimap2 (v2.17), we also used minimap2 (Li 2018) (v2.17) to map the reads on the reference genome, as input to cuteSV, Sniffles2, and LRcaller.
For LRcaller and Sniffles2, the most memory demanding step among the whole genotyping process was the read mapping with minimap2.

Both SVJedi-graph and SVJedi showed better performances on insertions than deletions, contrary to the other three SV callers that have in common to rely primarily on read mapping on the reference genome only.
SVJedi-graph attributed a genotype to 98% of the 17 637 discovered SVs.

Running SVJedi-graph on simulated sets of close and overlapping deletions showed that this graph model prevents the bias toward the reference alleles and allows maintaining high genotyping accuracy whatever the SV proximity, contrary to other state of the art genotypers.
Indeed, CuteSV and Sniffles genotypings are derived from discovery methods and rely on the same input data, namely reads mapped on the reference genome.
CuteSV and Sniffles2 were run with their "force call" option to genotype a given set of SVs, bypassing the SV discovery steps.
CuteSV and Sniffles genotyping accuracy starts decreasing as soon as deletions are <1000 bp apart, falling $80% and 90%, respectively, for overlapping or adjacent deletions.
Currently, SVJedi-graph can genotype five types of SVs: deletions, insertions, duplications, inversions, and intrachromosomal translocations.

We applied SVJedi-graph on an SV callset obtained by running a single SV discovery tool, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al. 2018), on PacBio CLR reads data from HG002 individual, containing 17 637 discovered SVs, with 7921 deletions and 9517 insertions.

Contrary to SVJedi-graph, all other genotypers but SVJedi show a higher genotyping accuracy with HiFi and ONT reads compared to CLR reads, Sniffles2 and LRcaller having their best genotyping accuracy on this SV set with the HiFi reads (89.4% and 86.2%, respectively), and cuteSV having its best genotyping accuracy with the ONT reads (92.7%).
As concerns SVJedi-graph results, the regions with higher densities of SVs and overlapping SVs did not harbor more missing or different genotypes as in the GIAB set.

However, only SVJedi strictly avoids the reference bias by mapping all the reads on all allelic sequences, whereas VaPoR and LRcaller perform first a selection of the reads to be mapped on alleles based on a whole reference genome alignment given as input.
All tools but Sniffles2 were run using 20 CPU threads.

Additionally, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al. 2018) and CuteSV (Jiang et al. 2020), which are discovery tools, also provide a genotyping mode as an option, but the methods implemented for these optional modes have not been described in any publication.
In conclusion, SVJedi-graph is a fast and efficient tool to genotype SVs with long-read data, that promises to be useful in the ever-growing number of population-scale SV studies.

On the other hand, SVJedi maintains its high accuracy but its genotyping rate decreases regularly with the deletion proximity.

Notably, the total SVJedi-graph time is similar to the genotyping time alone, for tools that require a mapping to the reference genome (CuteSV, Sniffles2, LRcaller), considering this file may have been obtained previously for other purposes.
Indeed, CuteSV and Sniffles genotypings are derived from discovery methods and rely on the same input data, namely reads mapped on the reference genome.
Results: We present SVJedi-graph, a novel method for SV genotyping that relies on a variation graph to represent in a single data structure all alleles of a set of SVs.

Both SVJedi-graph and SVJedi showed better performances on insertions than deletions, contrary to the other three SV callers that have in common to rely primarily on read mapping on the reference genome only.
This was to be expected for SVJedi as it constructs linear allelic sequences around each SV breakpoint independently of the other SVs in the set.
With the 30Â CLR PacBio reads, SVJedi-graph was able to genotype 99% of the SVs with a genotyping accuracy of 94.6% (Tables 1 and2).
When including the mapping time, SVJedi-graph took less than half an hour to genotype the whole High confidence HG002 SV callset with 30Â PacBio CLR reads.

In terms of memory requirements, SVJedi-graph was in a similar order of magnitude than SVJedi and the two are the less memory demanding tools of the five tested, while LRcaller and Sniffles2 required about 1.5-2 times more memory, and cuteSV about three times more.

The total running time shown for SVJedi-graph and SVJedi includes the SV representation step (allelic linear sequences for SVJedi and variation graph for SVJedi-graph) in addition to the mapping and genotyping time.
Illustration of the four steps of SVJedi-graph.
It is to be noted that cuteSV and LRcaller seem to systematically assign a genotype to all input SVs, thus having a fixed genotyping rate of 100% whatever the SV set.

The drop in accuracy is smaller for LRcaller, which maintains its accuracy above 97% for even very close deletions, but falls below 90% for overlapping deletions with the largest overlaps.

The memory requirement shown for cuteSV, Sniffles2 and LRcaller is the maximum amount of memory used by either the genotyper or minimap2.
On the human gold standard HG002 dataset, SVJedi-graph obtained the best performances, genotyping 99.5% of the high confidence SV callset with an accuracy of 95% in less than 30 min.

Additionally, Sniffles (Sedlazeck et al. 2018) and CuteSV (Jiang et al. 2020), which are discovery tools, also provide a genotyping mode as an option, but the methods implemented for these optional modes have not been described in any publication.
We use the same likelihood formula as in SVJedi and CuteSV (Lecompte et al. 2020;Jiang et al. 2020), which is described in Nielsen et al. (2011).

In the case of insertions, we notably observed that SVJedi-graph had the best genotyping accuracy but was not able to genotype more than 25% of them due to insufficient read support (less than three reads) for both alleles combined.

This may be explained by the fact that the mapping in SVJedi-graph was performed with the same default parameters of minigraph for all sequencing technologies, whereas the mapping used by other tools was performed with sequencing technology specific parameter presets of minimap2.
The memory requirement shown for cuteSV, Sniffles2 and LRcaller is the maximum amount of memory used by either the genotyper or minimap2.
As duplications are a special case of insertions, SVJedi-graph supports also duplications, as long as their duplicated sequence is characterized and reported similarly to insertions.

On this dataset dedicated to the evaluation of SV tools, SVJedi-graph obtained substantial improvement in genotyping accuracy and rate with PacBio CLR and HiFi reads compared to the other tested genotypers and in much less time.

As the High confidence set contains only distant SVs, we wanted to explore our method's performances on a more challenging SV set and we applied SVJedi-graph on another SV set from the HG002 GIAB callsets, called "ClusteredCalls" (that are included in the more difficult Tier 2 regions).

We could not find any association or relationship between missing and error genotypes with SV size or Tandem Repeat context (as was the case for SVJedi in their publication; Lecompte et al. 2020) to explain the lower concordance of genotypes.

On this dataset dedicated to the evaluation of SV tools, SVJedi-graph obtained substantial improvement in genotyping accuracy and rate with PacBio CLR and HiFi reads compared to the other tested genotypers and in much less time.

Notably, the total SVJedi-graph time is similar to the genotyping time alone, for tools that require a mapping to the reference genome (CuteSV, Sniffles2, LRcaller), considering this file may have been obtained previously for other purposes.

The four other tested genotyping tools present a lower accuracy than SVJedi-graph on the global SV set (92.2%, 88.7%, 85.4%, and 83.6% for SVJedi, cuteSV, Sniffles2, and LRcaller, respectively), as well as on both deletion and insertion subsets (Table 2).
reference bias in SVjedi-graph is the fact that it obtained similar performances between insertions and deletions in the real human benchmark SV set, in contrast to LRcaller and Sniffles.

In terms of memory requirements, SVJedi-graph was in a similar order of magnitude than SVJedi and the two are the less memory demanding tools of the five tested, while LRcaller and Sniffles2 required about 1.5-2 times more memory, and cuteSV about three times more.

The four other tested genotyping tools present a lower accuracy than SVJedi-graph on the global SV set (92.2%, 88.7%, 85.4%, and 83.6% for SVJedi, cuteSV, Sniffles2, and LRcaller, respectively), as well as on both deletion and insertion subsets (Table 2).

This is similar and even higher than the accuracy obtained on the curated high confidence set and this indicates that the presence of noise in the SV set does not prevent SVJedi-graph to accurately genotype true positive calls.

We could not find any association or relationship between missing and error genotypes with SV size or Tandem Repeat context (as was the case for SVJedi in their publication; Lecompte et al. 2020) to explain the lower concordance of genotypes.
reference bias in SVjedi-graph is the fact that it obtained similar performances between insertions and deletions in the real human benchmark SV set, in contrast to LRcaller and Sniffles.

In terms of memory requirements, SVJedi-graph was in a similar order of magnitude than SVJedi and the two are the less memory demanding tools of the five tested, while LRcaller and Sniffles2 required about 1.5-2 times more memory, and cuteSV about three times more.
Our tool was able to assign a genotype to 81.5% of these SVs, and 69.4% of them with an identical genotype to the one indicated in the GIAB set, the highest value being 71.4% obtained by CuteSV.

Our experiment on a whole raw and uncurated discovery call set represents a practical and realistic intermediate between the high confidence and the most challenging call sets and showed that SVJedi-graph is usable and obtains good quality results in practice in a few dozens of minutes on a whole human genome dataset.

As the High confidence set contains only distant SVs, we wanted to explore our method's performances on a more challenging SV set and we applied SVJedi-graph on another SV set from the HG002 GIAB callsets, called "ClusteredCalls" (that are included in the more difficult Tier 2 regions).

Contrary to SVJedi-graph, all other genotypers but SVJedi show a higher genotyping accuracy with HiFi and ONT reads compared to CLR reads, Sniffles2 and LRcaller having their best genotyping accuracy on this SV set with the HiFi reads (89.4% and 86.2%, respectively), and cuteSV having its best genotyping accuracy with the ONT reads (92.7%).

The higher genotyping accuracy of deletions over insertions observed with SVJedi-graph is also observed with cuteSV, LRcaller and Sniffles2, at an even more pronounced level, from 3.7 point % difference with cuteSV to 10 with Sniffles2.

This highly curated set, referred as High confidence, contains 5464 deletions and 7281 insertions of at least 50 bp which are distant from one another from at least 1 kb, whose genotypes are heterozygous or homozygous for the alternative allele in HG002 (Tier 1 set v.0.6 with the tag "PASS" in the VCF FILTER field) We applied SVJedi-graph on this set with three longread datasets from the HG002 individual obtained with different sequencing technologies, namely PacBio CLR, PacBio HiFi and Nanopore (ONT), and provided by GIAB (see Supplementary Material for download links).

As genome sequencing is more and more achieved with long-read technologies, even for population scale studies (Coster et al. 2021), and because the large size of the reads has an undeniable benefit on the quality of SV analyses (for genotyping as well as for discovery) (Mahmoud et al. 2019, Duan et al. 2022), a few tools dedicated to SV genotyping with long-read data have been proposed these last years, namely VaPoR (Zhao et al. 2017), SVJedi (Lecompte et al. 2020), and LRcaller (Beyter et al. 2021).

As genome sequencing is more and more achieved with long-read technologies, even for population scale studies (Coster et al. 2021), and because the large size of the reads has an undeniable benefit on the quality of SV analyses (for genotyping as well as for discovery) (Mahmoud et al. 2019, Duan et al. 2022), a few tools dedicated to SV genotyping with long-read data have been proposed these last years, namely VaPoR (Zhao et al. 2017), SVJedi (Lecompte et al. 2020), and LRcaller (Beyter et al. 2021).

As genome sequencing is more and more achieved with long-read technologies, even for population scale studies (Coster et al. 2021), and because the large size of the reads has an undeniable benefit on the quality of SV analyses (for genotyping as well as for discovery) (Mahmoud et al. 2019, Duan et al. 2022), a few tools dedicated to SV genotyping with long-read data have been proposed these last years, namely VaPoR (Zhao et al. 2017), SVJedi (Lecompte et al. 2020), and LRcaller (Beyter et al. 2021).

This highly curated set, referred as High confidence, contains 5464 deletions and 7281 insertions of at least 50 bp which are distant from one another from at least 1 kb, whose genotypes are heterozygous or homozygous for the alternative allele in HG002 (Tier 1 set v.0.6 with the tag "PASS" in the VCF FILTER field) We applied SVJedi-graph on this set with three longread datasets from the HG002 individual obtained with different sequencing technologies, namely PacBio CLR, PacBio HiFi and Nanopore (ONT), and provided by GIAB (see Supplementary Material for download links).
